profileText: (Nephew of James I. Roosevelt and uncle of Theodore Roosevelt), a Representative from New York; born in New York City August 7, 1829; completed preparatory studies; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1850 and commenced practice in New York City; fish commissioner of the State of New York 1868-1888; for several years edited the New York Citizen; elected as a Democrat to the Forty-second Congress (March 4, 1871-March 3, 1873); appointed by President Cleveland as Minister to The Hague and served from 1888 to 1890; treasurer of the Democratic National Committee in 1892; member of the Board of Aldermen of New York City; served as trustee representing the city of New York for the New York and Brooklyn Bridge from 1879 to 1882; died in Sayville, Suffolk County, N.Y., on June 14, 1906; interment in Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, N.Y.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Roosevelt, Robert Barnwell. Early New York; an address by Hon. Robert B. Roosevelt delivered before the New York society of the Order of the Founders and Patriots of America, January 15, 1904. [New York: N.p., 1904].
------. Fish culture compared in importance with agriculture. Washington: F. & J. Rives and G. A. Bailey, printers, 1872.
------. Five acres too much. New York: O. Judd Co., 1885.

------. Florida and the game water-birds of the Atlantic coast and the lakes of the United States [microform]: With a full account of the reporting along our seashores and inland waters, and remarks on breech-loaders and hammerless guns. New York: Orange Judd, 1884.

------. The game birds of the coasts and lakes of the northern states of America. A full account of the sporting along our sea-shores and inland waters, with a comparison of the merits of breech-loaders and muzzle-loaders. New York: Carleton, 1866.
------. The game fish of the Northern States and British Provinces. New York: Orange Judd Company, 1884.
------. Game Fish of the Northern States of America. New York: Arno Press, 1967.
------. Is Democracy dishonesty? New York: Journeymen Printers' Co-operative Association, 1871.
------. Love and luck, the story of a summer's loitering on the Great South Bay. New York: Harper & Brothers, 1886.
------. Progressive petticoats. New York: G. W. Carleton & Co. [etc., etc.], 1874.

------. Superior Fishing: The Striped Bass, Trout, and Black Bass of the Northern States. New York: Carleton, 1865. Reprint, with a new introduction by Ernest Schwiebert. St. Paul: Minnesota Historical Society Press, 1985.
------. The Washington City Ring. Washington: F. & J. Rives & G. A. Bailey, printers, 1873.

researchRecord.name: 1852-1864. 44 pages.
researchRecord.description: History of the spoliation of the Granssevort property.

researchRecord.name: 1873-1890's. 55 items.
researchRecord.description: Minutes of Commissioner of Fisheries, New York; scrapbook of clippings and photographs, and account book.

researchRecord.name: 1862. 1 container.
researchRecord.description: Letters and journal from his Civil War service in Washington, DC. Described in published report (1932).

researchRecord.name: In Theodore Roosevelt papers, 1759-1920.
researchRecord.description: 1,148 containers. Published index. Also on microfilm (485 reels).
